text:
I also used 2 cups brown sugar, 1 cup peanut butter and 3 cups powdered sugar, as suggested by other cooks.  After stirring the peanut butter into the brown sugar mixture, I poured it into my electric mixer and added the powdered sugar, beating until well blended, then pressed it into an 8"x8" dish and covered with plastic. It turned out delicious and creamy! Note: When boiling for 2 minutes, bring it to a "hard, rolling boil" before starting to time.

text:
Apparently I did something wrong, although I followed the instructions EXACTLY!!  Everything was going fine in the saucepan, and then I poured it into the sugar as instructed.  I used my mixer to blend, the sugar incorporated well, but it never became "smooth", even after 5 minutes of beating.  It was just a bowl of pebbles basically.  I thought I'd go ahead and press it into the pan anyways to see what would happen.  Oh MAN!  What a disaster.  The butter FLOATED to the top!!  If I had put it in the fridge like that, there would have been a layer of hardened butter on top!!  Please someone tell me what happened!

text:
Wonderful fudge!  This was my first attempt at fudge and it turned out perfectly.  I would highly recommend this recipe.  Hint: Line the pan with Saran Wrap before pouring in the fudge.  When the fudge has cooled, you can just pop it out of the pan and peel off the Saran Wrap.  This gives the fudge a smooth professional look and gives you no sticky pan to clean!

text:
This is the best peanut butter fudge I have ever made and have been making it for several years.  The first time I tried it, I waited for a full rolling boil and it ended up too hard, so I start timing just as soon as I see small bubbles.  It turns out perfect every time.  I am a southern girl from the "boil and drop in cold water" school.  But, I have won numerous fudge contests with this recipe and will never go back to boiling and dropping.

userID:

Display Name:
OkinawanPrincess

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I greased the 8 x 8-inch pan with butter then lined the pan with saran wrap to make clean-up and cutting easier.  I reduced brown sugar down to 2 cups, powdered sugar to 3 cups and I used 1 cup of Skippy’s creamy peanut butter. I used heavy whipping cream for the ½ cup of the milk called for in the recipe. I brought the butter, brown sugar and milk to a hard rolling boil. From the second I saw small bubbles break the surface I took it off the heat exactly two minutes afterwards and poured in the peanut butter and vanilla. I made sure to sift the confectioners' sugar to avoid any lumps then used an electric mixer to reach a smooth consistency. After about 2 minutes of mixing I noticed the peanut butter pulled away from the edge of the bowl and formed a smooth lump-free batter. I poured the peanut butter fudge into the lined 8x8 pan and chilled it. This fudge gave a smooth creamy professional look. I used the overlapping saran wrap to lift up the fudge and cut into bars. This is rich, super creamy and satisfying! I can taste the peanut butter flavor however, some might want a stronger peanut butter taste. I thought this was slightly too sweet for me but everyone thought this was fabulously-rich and creamy! This was easy to make and we all enjoyed this!

text:
To avoid getting crumbly, or weird little balls to form, leave the milk out till it is room temperature. It does that because the cold milk solidifies the melted butter.

userID:

Display Name:
1JOHN513

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
After reading many reviews, the first time I made this I started the 2 minute timer well before the rolling boil but after the first bubble. I also stirred it frequently, as per the directions. However, that was obviously NOT the way to do it, since mine also turned out to be a bowl full of pebbles, even after mixing the holy heck out of it with my kitchen aid for more than 5 minutes. So I tried again w/these changes: 1/ I DID NOT STIR THE MIXTURE during the 2 minutes, and 2/ began the 2 minute timer at the first bubble. It went totally against my grain because at the end of 2 mins. it was barely a rolling boil. However, I soldiered on and it turned out very  nice. And yes, the p. sugar lumps did beat out and it ended up very smooth. Not quite pourable, however, and I had to spoon it into my pan. I also used the suggestions made by many reviewers, reducing sugars and increasing peanut butter. It is still pretty darn sweet, but maybe when it's completely set and firm, the sweetness will dissipate somewhat. Also, the peanut butter taste is not very strong, but that's how I like it. Thinking about why some people couldn't successfully cook it for 2 minutes after the rolling boil, the only thing I could think of was the type of pot used and the stove top temperature. My pot is a very good, heavy stainless steel and I have a gas stove, so "medium heat" is pretty subjective. I hope this helps  you.

text:
We once forgot to add the powdered sugar, so we made again as the recipe directed. Forget it! Leaving out the powdered sugar gave a BETTER peanut flavor, stayed creamy, and is preferred by all of us-- even my sweet-tooth hubby! Five stars with changes. So good, and not too sweet with 1 cup PB, and 2 cups brown sugar (2 1/4 cups = 1 pound). Using my Kitchenaid to whip the syrup into the peanut butter (whip until thickened but still pourable) gave it a melt-in-your-mouth texture. It seemed to taste even better the next day.

None
text:
My husband loves PB fudge, and has trouble finding kinds that taste peanut-buttery enough.  This is awesome, great PB taste, wonderful texture. I used the 1 c PB, 2 c brown sugar 3 c pow sugar recommendations. For those who had trouble with butter floating to the top, or crumbly when mixing in the pow sugar, I think it's the cooking time.  I timed it from the second I saw two bubbles break the surface, then exactly two minutes after I took it off the heat. After mixing in the powdered sugar it was still of pourable consistancy.  It did look a bit shiny on top as it cooled ( COOL AT ROOM TEMPERATURE! )  but that went away when it cooled completely.  Do not refrigerate the fudge!

I can't believe it.  After 40 years of trying to make a decent fudge I have finally done it.  Thank you. Thank you.  This fudge is delicious. I had no problems making it.  I put the powdered sugar in a big mixing bowl - boiled everything for about 2 1/2 minutes - beat everything together (I did use only 3 cups of powdered sugar) and poured in a dish.  Couldn't have been easier or better.

text:
I gave it  four stars, after reading the other reviews I fixed the recipe up a bit. THese were very creamy and very good. Just to help out the person who wasn't quite sure. Make sure when you bring the butter and brown sugar to a boil you stop when it reaches the soft ball stage. Don't under boil and don't over boil. DOn't boil too fast either. Fudge is something you really need to watch. And make sure you read other helpful reviews too. SOmetimes recipes aren't quite right. And follow directions carefully. Fudge is really easy, but also really easy to mess up if you aren't careful. if you bring it to a boil quickly and then let it boil for exactly two minutes it may not turn out right. Bring to a boil slowly while constantly stirring and then let it boil only til the bubbles consume the top of it. Then remove it from the heat and finish the directions.

text:
Best I've ever tasted, including fudge-shop made. Here's what I used:

½ cup butter
2 cups brown sugar
½ cup milk
1 cup peanut butter
1 teaspoon vanilla extract
3 cups confectioners' sugar

I made this, then made a layer of Rocky Road fudge, and laid it down on top. It may just be the best fudge ever!

personally i don't like fudge, however i did make this fudge for the rest of my family and lets just say it got rave reviews. One tip though SIFT THE POWDERED SUGAR!!!!! and add it 1 cup at a time to the pot mixture....easier to handle and if it starts to cool down, turn the heat on low until you have finished incorperating the powder sugar.

text:
Wow, what a nice rich, creamy, delicious fudge! This is a great recipe for those of us who are not experienced candy makers. I followed the other reviewers suggestions and used 1 cup PB, 2 cups of brown sugar and 3 cups of confectioners sugar.  Also, this recipe says it makes 15 servings. If that's true, it's 15 very large pieces. I cut mine smaller (which you can get away with because it's so rich) and got closer to 40.

text:
I followed this recipe exactly the first time I made it, and it was a little too sweet and not quite peanut-buttery enough. This second time, I modified it the way others have suggested: 2 cups brown sugar, 3 cups powdered sugar, 1 cup peanut butter. I also used Smart Balance peanut butter, which isn't quite as sweet as some of the regular brands, and used my kitchen aid mixer to get it a bit smoother this time. The end result: sheer perfection. With the slight modifications to the recipe, this fudge is to die for.

country:
None
text:
Awesome! The Best. And awfully hard to kill. The recipe amounts are forgiving, you can experiment a little with flavour.  It also works equally as well with ICING SUGAR as it does with ICING MIXTURE (added later: and caster sugar if niether are available!) . The MAIN TRICK is to not boil it  too long. Soft ball (drop a little in a glass of water a soft ball will form) stage will give a lovely creamy consistency. If it gets too hot (boils too long) you may end up with dry pebbles as your sugar tries to head off to toffee land (I'm Australian if you're not sure what I mean). (addition:) Also, works as well with smooth, cruncy, sugar/salt free fresh smashed pb - whatever's yr thing. ENJOY

My initial review for this was so/so, because it was too sweet and void of any real peanut butter taste.  I made a second batch, but this time I used 2 1/4 c of brown sugar, 3 cups of powdered sugar and 1 1/2 cups of peanut butter and it's DIVINE!  Perfectly sweet with lots of good peanut butter flavor!  I also kneaded it about 7 times to ensure it was smooth and the powdered sugar was incorporated.  The rating I'm giving is for the original recipe.

This was really good and actually the first fudge I've made that turned out well.  However, I would suggest reducing the brown sugar to about 2 C or a little less and increasing the peanut butter to about 1 C.  You may also want to decrease the confectioner's sugar but I don't know if that would intefere with the firmness.  Recipe as is, is very sweet.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a fantastic recipe.  I've made it several times, sometimes following the recipe exactly and sometimes using a few variations.  It's so easy, and it always turns out.  I did find that my family prefers the recipe using LIGHT brown sugar (the recipe simply states "brown sugar").  Dark brown sugar changed the taste and made it more caramel-ly, if that makes sense.  It took away from the peanut butter taste.  I also found that we preferred to use crunchy peanut butter.  It just gives it a little something extra.  I also highly recommend the recipe using other reviewers' changes: 3C confectioner's sugar, 2C brown sugar, and 1C peanut butter.

text:
This is a great recipe, very easy and cheaper to make than some of the other peanut butter fudge recipes. I followed suggestions of others and used 2 cups of brown sugar, 1 cup of peanut butter, and 3 cups of confectioners' sugar. After the first appearance of bubbles, I waited until the mixture came to a medium boil before I started the 2 minute timer. The result was FANTASTIC, super creamy fudge!   (Be sure to sift the confectioners' sugar or else you will have lumps.)

text:
Very easy & very good fudge but I'm looking for the best peanut butter fudge.  I'll use this until I find it!  Just a small tip to peoples fudge that doesn't set.  Make sure it is boiling before you time it for 2 min.  On another recipe I tried I started timing it when it wasn't even boiling & the recipe didn't set for me.

text:
I haven't tried this recipe as of yet and would like to ask those who did not like it, to try this, 
First was it dry or rainy the day you first tried this ?
Second what altitude are you at?
Third was it "cane" sugar or "beet" sugar you used the first time?
Between my Grandmother letting me know about the different sugars and my Sister Sally living at high altitudes I have learned that those are two factors in candy making that will make a difference and neighbor told me about the humidity, when my children were small.
If you can remember these factors it could help you next time.
I am going to try this over Christmas vacation for my Grandkids. 
Wish me luck.

text:
Absolutly amazing!  I'm 16 years old, and this was my first time making any sort of thing like this.  It was the easiest thing!  No room to mess up here.  I followed everyone's instructions on reducing the sugar, and it still came out very sweet.. it would probably have been too sweet if I didn't reduce the sugar.  

I found nothing wrong with the recipe!  Well, except the amount of fat, but hey, it was well worth it!!  My dad (aka my taste tester!) absolutly loved it.  His only complaint was there not being enough!  

This recipe did not last long in my house.  I've already been asked many times to make it again (4th time!).  A friend of mine told me she'd pay me to make her half a pan of this fudge.

It's a fan with everyone.  Big hit.  Try it, you wont regret it, and there's really no way to mess it up.

However, one tip, make sure you beat it long enough (I'd say 3 or 4 minutes continuous) or else it will be a bit liquidy and shmooshy.

text:
This was a super easy recipe. I followed the advice of other reviewers and used 3 cups confectioners sugar, 1 cup peanut butter and 2 cups brown sugar ( I actually used 1 white and 1 brown since I only had 1 cup of brown). I let the sugar/butter mixture come to a rolling boil and timed it for 2 minutes then removed from heat added the peanut butter and vanilla then SLOWLY added (1/2 c. at a time) the powered sugar to the pot which I was stirring with a wisk. It is a good arm workout but the fudge turned out smooth and yummy. :O)

I tried this one when I didn't have the marshmallow creme needed for another one, and honestly this was only so-so.  I thought the texture was too crumbly and dry. text:
Trick for me: whip the peanut butter before hand!  I found that whipping the peanut butter, just with a spoon, helped me get it blended with the hot liquid faster.  This is the best fudge I have ever made, and was so glad it did not involve marshmallow creme! :-)  Couple things: Be sure to heat as it says, MEDIUM!  I have ruined a different recipe because I got in a hurry.    In all it took me a good 20 minutes start to finish, but so worth it.    I tossed walnuts in with the powdered sugar too.  Great!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
In my first attempt at making some fudge, I wanted a recipe that was pretty easy to follow and this was it!! I made this recipe today and my peanut butter fudge turned out great. I followed the comments that were made from other reviews and used 2 cups brown sugar, 1 cup peanut butter, and 3 cups confectioner's sugar (well I didnt exactly have 3 cups but it still turned out great!). I also made sure that the mixture was at a hard rolling boil before i started to time it for 2 minutes. Once i had taken it off of the heat and added in the peanut butter and vanilla in, it had started to thicken up rather quickly so i had to quickly beat in the confectioners's sugar (beated it in on low heat). This is a very easy recipe and I will definately make it again!!

Mixed reviews on this recipe. I followed the changes others suggested,3cps. confectioners sugar, 2 cups brown sugar, and 1 cup peanutbutter. After pouring in the pan I left it out on the counter to "chill" since many others said not to refrigerate. I tried it about 2 hrs later and it had a soft consistency, not fudgelike. I put it in the refrigerator overnight hoping it would harden, which it did, but still not the consistency of what I think of fudge.  Took it to a family cookout and some really liked it and some were just ok with it. I might try it again another time but will look for another recipe in the mean time.

text:
After a coworker brought some peanut butter fudge her mother-in-law made, I was determined to find my own recipe. This tastes SO good -- it's just like the fudge I had!
I sifted two cups of the powdered sugar into a large bowl, where I used my mixer to blend it with the peanut butter and vanilla. While I was doing this, I had the other stuff on a slow boil on the stove. I greased up a pan, poured it all in, and had no powdered sugar lumps. It's setting in the fridge right now, but I had to lick the spatula -- it tastes great!

userID:

Display Name:
LISITSA

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677177.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe was absolutely delicious and I had no problems with it.  My mother and grandmother, who hate peanut butter, started munching on the fudge before it was even cold.  I followed previous reviewers' suggestions, decreasing the powdered sugar to 3 cups and the brown sugar to 2 cups and increasing the peanut butter to 1 cup.  Also, since I had no creamy peanut butter, I used crunchy peanut butter.  It added a delightful taste.  I also was low on milk, so I used 1/4 cup milk and 1/4 cup heavy cream, and the fudge seemed to set up perfectly.  I would suggest sifting the powdered sugar before measuring it, and mixing the fudge with an electric beater at the very end.  Also, I had 1/4 cup of leftover mini chocolate chips, which I stirred in after everything was mixed and slightly cooled.  It gave the fudge a wonderful marbled look without making it too chocolate-y.

This was very easy to make and tastes great! For those of you thinking about making this, remember that if the PB says on the jar 18oz that is it's WEIGHT. A cup of PB is over half of an 18oz jar.I used the 1 cup PB, 2 cups BrS, 3 cups CS, that others had mentioned and it worked wonderfully. Yummy!

recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1815834.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Following the advice of many others, I too reduced the brown sugar to 2 cups, Increased the peanut butter to 1 cup, and reduced the powered sugar to 3 cups. When it came to boiling, I started the two minute time after it came to a boil. When I added the peanut butter and vanilla, I didn't remove from the heat, I just kept it on simmer. I sifted the powered sugar to avoid it being chunky. When I finally added the peanut butter mix, it was very easy to mix at a medium speed. I put everything in an 8x8 greased foiled lined dish, for easy removal.

text:
I made this for Christmas and forgot to review it until now. The taste was very yummy, however the texture was crumbly. I let it set in the fridge and then tried cutting it, but it was crumbling rather than cutting. So I then let it sit out for a few minutes and tried cutting again. Much better! If you store this in the fridge, it will be crumbly if eaten right away. I suggest taking it out of the fridge for a few minutes before serving. It makes it 100x better! Thanks for the great recipe!

4
favoritesCount:

recipesCount:

reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674138.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Ok, so i made this peanut butter fudge according to recommendations from other reviewers, with 2C. brown sugar and 3C. powdered/confectioners sugar. While i was boiling the butter/milk/brown sugar mixture, instead of only boiling for 2 minutes, i continued to boil the mixture at med-high heat for about 5-7 minutes and used a candy thermometer to check the tempurature of the mixture, waiting until it was close to the soft ball stage and just to be sure, i also did the "drop in cold water" method. When i was satisfied that it was up to temp, i added the peanut butter and vanilla, and found that the mixture was already starting to "set/thicken" like proper peanut butter fudge would, but i did however finish the recipe as it says and added the powdered sugar. While mixing with my hand mixer i found i had to add another 1/4 C of milk because the mixture was becoming crumbly and not smooth at all. still came out good but a little tip. if you wait till the sugar/butter/milk mixture reaches soft ball stage, you really dont need the powdered sugar because it will set properly on its own and will taste much more like proper old fashioned peanut butter fudge.

text:
As with the last several reviews, I increased the PB to 1 cup, decreased the brown sugar to two cups and the confectioners' sugar to three cups.  Even so, this fudge is EXTREMELY sweet.  Even with the changes, it still uses 5 cups of sugar for a yield of 15 pieces.  I am usually a big sweets fan...baking is my favorite.  I honestly don't ever remember saying that anything was "too" sweet.  However, this recipe fit that description.  I am really surprised at how many people did not mention this fact.  Overall, the fudge had a good consistency, but was just too sweet.  I would recommend going with a recipe that uses marshmallow or marshmallow cream.  They tend to come out with a much more "peanuty" flavor!

Honestly as I made this I was thinking two stars. I had the same problem as others with the crumble factor. The recipe states to beat until smooth...after reducing the brown sugar and powdered sugar adding more peanut butter and a touch more milk it was still just crubmbles. I ended up pressing everything into the pan and fridging it for 4 hours and OH MY! SOOOOO good! So don't panic if you see crumbles. It is worth it!

text:
I used 1 cup peanut butter, 2 cups brown sugar, and 3 cups powdered sugar (which I sifted) as others have suggested.  I set the timer for two minutes after it came to a good boil, as opposed to setting the timer as soon as I saw a few bubbles.  The fudge set up perfectly, had a good texture, and tasted pretty good.  I'm not a fan of peanut butter fudge that has a strong brown sugar taste as this one does, so I'll be going back to the recipe for Creamy Peanut Butter Fudge on this site, which I prefer.

text:
This was really easy. I did have a slight problem mixing the confectioner's sugar in and to dissolve. It left chunks and took a lot of stirring. I chose this recipe because I have a limited amount of baking supplies/tools, so this might have turned out better if I had had an electric mixer. Still not bad though, just a little elbow grease required.   I followed others' advice and did the 3 cups confectioners, 2 cups brown sugar (1 cup light brown, 1 cup dark brown, just because of my supply), and 1 cup peanut butter. They were still really sweet, even though the sugar amount is less.   Due to the sweetness and inability for anybody to eat more than a half-inch chunk at a time, I was able to get about 60 pieces out of this, so about 20 servings. Originally I had planned on aking two batches for a party, but one turned out to be enough.   Thanks for the recipe, I'll probably try it again.

Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2008-01-16T20:27:57.493
helpfulCount:
3
userID:
1912117
Display Name:
roweena
isPro:
False
followersCount:
24
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
47
favoritesCount:
286
recipesCount:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/192049.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This fudge turned out FANTASTIC!  I took everyones suggestion at altering the sugar and pb amounts and I did sift the powdered sugar to get the lumps out.  I made sure to keep the stove on medium heat, being PATIENT and waiting for the brown sugar and butter mix to come to a boil, as I read somewhere that cranking up the heat can be a big mistake.  As soon as it started to bubble at a good rate I watches the time and took it off at exactly 2 minutes.  I had no problems incorporating the hot mixture with the powdered sugar using a hand mixer.  at the very end I mixed in a handful of bittersweet chocolate chips.  Now, I have never made fudge before and have only tried it a couple times in my life, not really a fan of fudge at all.  But I wanted to try it as many seem to like fudge for holiday gifts.  I have to say, I thought it was WAY too sweet at first...but I kept going back for more!  now I'm not really sure if it is too sweet, or I just needed to get used to the taste of "fudge" itself.  Next time I might try cutting down just a tablespoon or 2 on each of the sugars.  But beyond that, it is ADDICTIVE!  Just the right level of "creamy, melt in your mouth" and it set up perfectly.  It wasn't too soft or too hard, no crumbling, no lumping, cut like a dream with a sharp knife.  a keeper!!

text:
I love this  fudge, I make it all the time!. I think its a good idea to reduce the sugar, I just do it by eye. To anyone who has done this recipe and had it turn out crumby, this happened to me once, and I brought it to my neighbour who is a cook, and she told me that I had boiled it too long! Watch your boiling time very carefully!!

text:
A darker appearance and more complex flavor than the pnb fudge we usually make. Use a Kitchen Aid mixer for best results! The top gets just a little dry if not covered immediately. There was just a bit of graininess, so next time, I will cook it longer. The jury (the family, of course) is still out on this one. Don't know if it will replace our prize-winning recipe, but it's worth your time. The brown sugar gives it a caramel overtone.

text:
Being vegan, I used Earth Balance buttery spread (a really great non-hydrogenated margarine) and soy milk in this recipe. I left the PB and sugar (didn't pack the brown sugar) amounts as called for. I used "natural" peanut butter with the separated oil poured off, which makes the PB taste *really* peanutty, so the fudge was quite sweet AND quite peanutty.

I beat the liquid into sifted powdered sugar by hand, which was a little difficult. A hand mixer would have been easier, I think. All in all, the fudge turned out great! My husband LOVED it.

text:
This is a GOOD fudge recipe. But I only say Good and not Great because it's too sweet and not enough peanut butter taste so that's why it only received 5 stars. I have made this twice now, first time exact recipe and the second with the suggested changes.  I reduced the brown sugar to 2 cups, upped the peanut butter to 1 cup, reduced the powdered sugar to 3 cups, and even subbed the 1/2 cup milk for heavy whipping cream. Now THAT was a 5 star fudge!  The texture was perfect, the peanut butter flavor just right and such a creaminess you wouldn't believe. Hubby took one bite and was like a kid in a candy store! He's made me promise over and over to save the recipe while he's going back for another piece.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
As many have said, up the peanut butter, down the sugar. It's waaaaaay too sugary by default and overpowers the peanut butter entirely. With a shift to 1 1/4 cup peanut butter and 1 3/4 brown sugar, it comes out pretty much perfect. As a borderline diabetic, my sugar tends to swing up and down wildly so I usually keep a bag of this recipe in the fridge. If I get a sugar low, grab a little piece and problem's solved. Stores for at least 3-4 weeks without issue as long as it's in the fridge. Again, to stress this once more, I love sugary stuff... and sometimes even physically need it, but DO NOT make the recipe as printed; ALWAYS swap half a cup of brown sugar for extra peanut butter instead!

userID:
8254732
Display Name:
M.Fawn
isPro:

3

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1083452.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've been looking for a fudge recipe for EVER that didn't come out crumbly and dry. I FOUND IT! This is hands down the best I've come across! Now, I did make some changes as the other reviews recommended, & here's what I did; I used 2cups brown sugar, 3 cups confectioners sugar, 2 tsp vanilla, 1 full cup of peanut butter. I was nervous about the boiling stage so here's what I did; I stirred the ingredients together ALOT until the first couple bubbles started, right away I started my 2 minute timer and I never stirred it for them full 2 minutes. It worked for me!!! Thanks so much for an amazing recipe, the fudge turned out creamy & smooth, just like at the bakers!!! My husband was SOOO excited for a perfect fudge!! :)

4

text:
I've made this (sort of ) recipe twice now. I did follow another reviewers advice and changed it to 2 cups brown sugar, 3 cups confectioners sugar and 1 cup peanut butter. So I can't compare with the original version, in all fairness. But what I can say is that the changes worked just fine both times. This is a HUGE crowd pleaser, and turned out 2 out of 2 times. And the first time, I even had to alter that a bit because I didn't have enough creamy peanut butter. I used about 1/4 cup crunchy peanut butter to make the cup called for. I actually think I preferred that batch over the full on creamy pb batch. But whatever. Both are good. The main thing that sells me on this recipe is that I usually have all the ingredients on hand and I can whip it up in no time. When I find a recipe that requires ingredients I have, can be made in a reasonable time frame, and makes the crowd roar, I consider it a keeper!

i had this recipe for 40 years and i made it all the years my children was growing up and they loved it one of my sons liked it with the chuncky peanut butter and the other two liked it the creamy way so i made both i also only used 3 cups of the confection sugar and 2 cups of the brown sugar but with the peanut butter i would by the reg. size i think its 12 0r 14oz and would use the whole bottle and it would come out wonderful so creamy and taste unreal but i would never store it in the frig. only because it would harden and become stale to fast ''' but then with 3 boys it never lasted that long anyways.thank God you have this posted and i found this recipe again because after  my sons got married i lost it and now i wanted to have it to bake some fudge for my church bake sale this sunday ,im so happy i found it again thank you so much God Bless You for having it still around (:

This was my first try at making any type of fudge. I was a bit concerned about the texture since it seemed lumpy/gritty when mixed.  Mixing at a lower speed for longer time seemed to help and it set very well.  The top did have a lot of oil when I spread it in the dish, but I absorbed what I could and that helped. Next time I'd probably reduce the butter since the PB naturally has a lot of oil. I also cut down the sugar and increased the PB based on other suggestions and it was still sweet enough!

userID:
3100118
Display Name:
Pooch656
isPro:
False
followersCount:
1
followingCount:

madeRecipesCount:
105
favoritesCount:
13
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/170896.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Love the taste of this fudge! I used the 1,2,3 cup change, but after mixing it all together added some spoonfuls more peanut butter and a pinch of salt to cut down the sweet. I sifted the confectioner's sugar and beat with a wooden spoon. I lined the dish with greaseproof paper. Fudge can be hard (no matter what people say) so here are my tips, bring the sugar up to boil gently don't just crank the heat up the whole time, I timed from when there were bubbles on most of the surface (if that helps), and I started from the center of the mix and worked the sugar in slowly from the outsides of the bowl when using a wooden spoon to stop lumps. If your mix went too hard or to pebbles it may be because you cooked the sugar/butter mix too long, boiling evaporates the water content so you may have to add some back in like others have done. On the flip side if it didn't set you may not have cooked it long enough (too much moisture in the butter mix which has happened to me HEAPS). If the butter separates it could be for the same reason, I'd just dab it off with paper towels. Never refrigerate fudge the sugar melts with all the moisture (hence why you're usually told to keep it in an airtight container.) Good eats has a good episode on this where Alton explains most of this so that might be helpful to watch if you're still stuck
Review:
Rating:
5

Thanks to all the reviews, I too made a few adjustments.  I used 2 cups of brown sugar, 1 cup of all natural peanut butter and 3 cups confectioners sugar.  When I beat it in the bowl, the mixture started to crumble, so I think it had something to do with the all natural peanut butter, I simply put it all in the pan, and used butter spray on the back of a spatula and pressed all the crumbs in the pan.  The next day, I cut it into squares and it was perfect.  My guests all loved it--I will be giving some out for Christmas gifts this year...thanks Angie!

Refrigerated peanut butter is most likely the cause of some of the mishaps listed.  Make sure your peanut butter is room temperature.

I used 3C confectioners sugar, 1C peanut butter & 2C brown sugar (as others suggested), and margarine instead of butter, my consistency was perfect, I just had to mix by hand.

text:
Hi Angie,This is the best and I do mean best. Last night I was readind the reviews and thought this recipe can't be as good and easy as everyone say's. I checked out the negative responses and had to find out for myself, I made it late last night and it was absolutely delicious, no problem at all it did not match the negative review's. I sifted my powdered sugar, did not pack the brown sugar as most recipe's call for, adjusted my sugar as suggested and made sure my burner was a low medium and made sure it was at a full boil for two min. Today I made it again and added a cup of choc. chips with the peanut butter. It is a winner, thank you so much.  TASU

text:
I used 2 cups light brown sugar, 1 cup Jif chunky peanut butter & 3 cups powdered sugar, also suggested by others.  After stirring the peanut butter into the brown sugar mixture, I poured it into my mixing bowl, then added the powdered sugar, beating until thoroughly blended.  Pressed it into an 8"x 8" Pyrex baking dish & covered w/plastic.  *Also note:  When boiling for 2 minutes, bring it to a "HARD, ROLLING BOIL" before starting to time it for the 2 minutes.  VERY Good:)

userID:
15075489
Display Name:
Keeping it Straight!
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
1
favoritesCount:
0
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674138.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I make a lot of candy and fudge for others especially over the holidays, I had some requests for PB fudge. I'm no fan of PB in any form but reluctantly agreed to make some.  I too followed the other reviewers with the adjustments in Brown sugar, Confec. sugar and PB. I always sift my confec. sugar when I use it which may help keep the fudge from getting pebbly as some reviews pointed out.  anyway, the recipe worked great, everyone absolutely loved it!  It was firm, smooth, creamy etc.  Even I thought it was good for being PB!

 I did measure my temp with my digital candy thermometer as it boiled, it came in right at 224 degrees ( here in Denver) when my 2 minutes where up, same as most all other fudge I make, this might help others seeing some were posting that they were having issues with when to start timing of boil, which could lead to a nasty loose mess or harder than wanted consistency.   Remember to adjust temp 2 degrees less for every 1000' in altitude you are above sea level.  SL = 234degrees.   Hopes this helps and keeps things consistent.  Best!

text:
This recipe is delish! I'm a serious peanut butter lover and I make it almost once a week, which is bad for my waistline but excellent for my tastebuds. I reduced the brown sugar to 2 cups, increased the peanut butter to 1 cup, and reduced the powdered sugar to 3 cups. I also put it into a 9x13in pan. It takes too long to cool in a smaller dish, and you still end up with a thick, hearty fudge from the bigger dish. Love, love, love this fudge!

I made this for the second time today!!  I grew up on my Grandmothers fudge, but have never been able to come anywhere to close to making it as good as hers.  In fact, I've always had a hard time getting my fudge to set.  It turned out perfectly the first time, per exact recipe.  This time I used a whole cup of peanut butter, for a little added flavor, and it turned out amazing again!!  
This recipe is unbelievably easy!!  I will probably be able to make it from memory the next time.    In my opinion, the best way to make this is to have everything measured out and ready to go before you start melting the butter!

GREAT Recipe! This is super easy and tastes fantastic. I used 1 cup of peanut butter and threw in a few handfuls of semisweet chocolate chips when I mixed in the peanut butter. Gave it a hint of chocolate! I used about 3 cups confectioners sugar also. I'd recommend maybe sifting in the powdered sugar as mine did have 'lumps' even after mixing it for a while. That certainly didnt affect the taste - it just looks like we used chunky peanut butter. Its even a great color!I sprayed my pan w/non-stick spray and it came out with no problems.

Okay, had to give it 3 because I decided to follow the advice of everyone and use 3,2,1. I have no idea how I did it, but mine tastes and has the same consistency as peanut butter blossom dough, and is extremely soft. EXTREMELY soft. No eggs or flour required. It's so similar, I'm almost tempted(almost, I know better) to bake a piece and see what happens :/ lol. I don't know if I overboiled or underboiled but it passed the soft ball stage test and stayed that way. It holds it's shape, but barely.

text:
This is a very good fudge recipe, me and my wife made it, but being i'm newly diabetic, we put a diabetic's twist to it., I took the advice of the other reveiwers and used 2 cups of Ideal brown sugar substitute (Xylitol, maltodextrin, molasses, & sucralose) and 3 cups of Ideal confectionery sugar substitute (Xylitol, maltodextrin, corn starch, sucralose),and being xylitol does asorb liquids, I added a little extra milk (about 1-2 tsp). even diabetics can enjoy the good life  without having that nasty tasting nutra-sweet/aspertame after taste. Thanks for the recipe!

text:
I followed others advice and opted to 2 cups brown sugar, 1 cup peanut butter, and 3 cups powder sugar. This came out great. I started the 2 min boil at the first sign of bubbles. I would strongly suggest using a stand-up electric mixer for the final step. Crank it up high and it will remove all the powder sugar lumps.

text:
I can't believe how fast and easy this recipe is without losing quality. I get so excited over recipes like this. The only thing I would suggest is when mixing in the confectioners sugar, you must be quick because the mixture will cool so fast, making the mixture too dry and hard to pour. If this happens just add more butter or peanut butter over low heat, stirring constantly.

text:
I have no idea what I did wrong, I followed the recipe exactly. But it turned out very dark and crumbly (it looked like cooked ground beef), and did not have much of a peanut buttery taste. I used dark brown sugar, so maybe that can account for the dark color?? I am supposed to be taking this to someone tomorrow as a holiday gift, so I'm going to stay up tonight and try another batch.  Okay, after the first batch turned out so horrible, I adjusted the recipe some. I used 2 loose cups of brown sugar and added 2 extra tablespoons of milk. I used 1 and 1/3 cup of peanut butter, and took the powdered sugar down to 2 and 1/4 cups. It turned out sooo much better!!!! I would give the adjusted recipe 4 stars :-D

text:
Yum!  This was my first attempt at making fudge and it turned out perfectly.  I did as other reviews suggested and used 2 cups of brown sugar, 1 cup of peanut butter and 3 cups of confectioners sugar.  I also lined the bottom of the dish with plastic wrap so that it made a nice smooth finish and was super easy to remove from the pan and then be cut into squares.  Can't wait to make this again.  It is very sweet...but it's fudge!  I may try it with natural peanut butter (no sugar added) next time.  Definitely a keeper!

This is my favorite recipe. It works so well. I find it hardens best if I let it chill for a hour then cut it into squares and let it chill another hour. This is also a great recipe for maple fudge, all you have to do is replace the peanut butter with 3/4 tsp of maple flavoring.

text:
I followed recommendations to reduce the sugar and increase the peanut butter, but the final product still tasted more like sugar than peanut butter.
I salvaged the fudge by cutting into small cubes and rolling in unsweetened cocoa powder.  The bitterness of the powder offsets the sweetness and actually allows the flavor of the peanut butter to come through.

text:
This is a pretty good peanut butter fudge recipe. It beats waiting until soft ball stage. One thing I must let everyone know: If you get a craving for peanut butter fudge but don't have enough powdered sugar to make this recipe.... just go to the store or wait. I tried making powdered sugar in the blender and this recipe did not come out the same at all. When I make it with store-bought powdered sugar it comes out perfectly.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Oh definitely will make this again! It's a great recipe but I would double all the ingredients because the serving was too little. However, it was way too sweet, even after I reduced the sugar to 2 cups of brown sugar and 2 cups of confectioners sugar. I think I would reduce it to 1 and a 1/2 cups of white sugar for future reference. And for all those people who didn't succeed the first time, make sure while you're dissolving the sugar into milk and butter that you heat slowly on low and increase the heat every 2 minutes until you get to medium heat. Don't start timing until it's a hard boil and make sure you don't over boil or under boil.

country:

text:
I make this all the time, but use 1/4 c. butter or margarine, 1/3 c. light karo syrup and 4 c. confectioners sugar.  It is sweet enough without adding more brown sugar.  Just smash it all together and pat down in an 8" by 8" pan.  No cooking, and so easy, can even add some crushed peanuts or even use crunchy peanut butter.  Still need the 1 t. vanilla, and can even add a dash of salt if desired.  Easy and delish.

text:
Awesome PB fudge!  After reading the reviews I made a few alterations. I reduced the brown sugar to 2 cups, increased the PB to 1 cup, and made sure I whisked the melted butter, brown sugar & milk until very, very smooth. When making fudge (I have asked Santa for a candy therometer this year) I tend to error on the side of caution and boil for half a minute or a minute less than stated, and never above medium-low (4 on my stove).

text:
AWESOME FUDGE! fudge was super easy to make. I followed all directions, except I did follow some users suggestions of: 3 cups of pwdr. sugar, 1 cup peanut butter, 2 cups brown sugar. I also used Evaporated Milk, gave it a richer taste! I used my mixer to incorporate the hot mixture w/ the powdered sugar. It became very smooth and cooled quickly. Line your pan w/ plastic wrap or foil for easy clean up and smooth appearance. I used a 9 x 13" pan and it made the perfect thickness for us. Fantastic Fudge Recipe!

text:
It's still chilling, but so far it looks like it's turning out great. I followed the advice of several other reviewers and did the whole 2 cups of brown sugar, 3 cups of powdered sugar, and 1 cup of PB. Since I don't have a mixer I did it all by hand (I don't recommend it...). Took about 5 minutes of vigorous mixing to get all the clumps of powdered sugar mixed in and for it to become smooth. Tasted great off the spoon. ;)

**UPDATE**
Tasted great and was a hit! A bit sweet, but tasty! The PB flavor was not overpowering at all and it came out just like regular fudge.

Thanks for the great recipe! I know what I'll be making this holiday seasoning for the gift baskets.

text:
This was surprisingly good, and easy too. I decreased the brown sugar to 2 cups as suggested by another review. I also cooked the brown sugar, butter and milk in the microwave instead of on the stove. It worked perfectly, I just checked on it after 2 minutes and made sure it was at soft ball stage. I also added a half bag of mini marshmallows to the hot mixture before adding the powdered sugar...makes it a bit creamier I think. Altogether, a good peanut butter dessert!

text:
I made this recently for my peanut-allergic son using Sunbutter in place of the peanut butter. I'm not sure if it was the sunflower seed butter, or if it's normal, but it didn't want to come together and got pretty oily on top. I was ready to throw the whole pan out when my (calm, cool, collected) husband stepped in and pressed it into the pan, blotted off the oil and put it away and said, "well, let's just wait and see". It turned out just fine. Not only did my son get to enjoy "peanut butter" fudge for the first time, but we were also able to share it with another man who used to be a huge peanut butter fan but recently became allergic. Yay!

text:
Well, I too ended up with a bowl of pebbles but was able to recover. I'm certain I boiled too long which caused the candy base to dry out -- instead of timing it I was using a candy thermometer and I think my thermometer has broken! Bummer. The candy base was not grainy though, so I figured I could still save the fudge. I just added a splash of heavy cream to moisten, then a spoonful of peanut butter to make it creamy again. Beat it then stirred and mashed it together. When I saw it was able to be smoothed I knew it was not ruined. It came out just great!

I only gave 4 stars though because even though it's delicious, I have another peanut butter fudge recipe that I think tastes slightly better (though it doesn't set up as well). I did the 2cup-1cup-3cup changes as mentioned in other reviews.

I followed the directions, exactly as stated. I even read 9 pages of reviews, just to be sure. Yet my fudge didnt turn out as I had hoped. The mixture in the pan was ok, then I added the peanut butter and vanilla, once removed, and mixed together. When I poured it over the c. sugar it was almost as if the sugar wasnt "melting" as it should. There were lumps all in it. I dont have a sifter, maybe that would have helped? Overall it mixed ok, I used a wooden spoon. I wasnt sure how long to beat it, because of the lumps. its cooling in the fridge, and aside from the c.sugar lump here and there it appears to be hardening like it should. I had a lick from the wooden spoon and the taste is out of this world. I love pretty much anything peanut butter, so I'm excited to try one!

text:
I also followed the advice of others and used 2 cups of brown sugar, 3 cups of powdered sugar, and 1 cup of peanut butter.  It came out PERFECT!  I used a hand mixer to blend the liquid with the powdered sugar and the fudge came out SO smooth and creamy!  My only mistake was using a store brand of peanut butter. My fudge was good but the taste of the peanut butter definitely comes through, so be sure and use a good brand like Skippy or Reeses. Also be sure your peanut butter is fresh. Mine was a newer jar but just had kind of an "old" taste, which of course I didn't realize until AFTER I made the fudge!  I know my fudge would have been even more awesome had I used better pb, so I give this recipe 5 stars!

text:
Just made this fudge for my husband.  It is easy and delicious.  I too made the following substitutions:  1/2 cup margarine (instead of butter), 2 cups brown sugar (soft and light), 1/2 cup 1% milk, 1 cup creamy peanut butter, 1 teaspoon vanilla, and 3 cups (unsifted) confectioners' sugar.  I put the confectioners' sugar in my Kitchen Aide bowl and poured the hot brown sugar mixture on top and mixed on low/medidum speed for a couple of minutes until everything was smooth and creamy.  I will make this again (& again).

This was great!! I give it 4 stars because I used the recommendations of previous reviewers.. My boyfriend and I still thought it could've used a bit more PB.. maybe 1 1/4c? But we really love peanut butter.. hahah. I used natural chunky PB because that's what we had and I had a pregnancy craving for fudge. :) It still turned out perfect and we actually liked the addition of the pieces of peanuts. I used my hand mixer to beat the PB/brown sugar mixture into the confectioner's sugar.. I wouldn't do it any other way. I'm not that strong! I think it probably turns out with a better texture that way. No problems with the butter separating or anything. YUMMMM!!!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I used the less brown sugar/more peanut butter recomendations, as my peanut butter has sugar in it. The first time I made this I thought "it's got to boil longer, to reach the right temp!" when I finally took it off the heat and poured it in the confectioners sugar, it immediately turned crumbly. I pressed it into the pan to cool. Tasty, but still crumbly. The second time, I boiled it for the two minutes, then took the sugar (in a sifter) and put the sugar into the fudge, about a 1/2 cup at a time, and mixed it by hand untill I felt like it was stiff enough. All together I used less than 2C of confectioners sugar. It turned out perfect! My husbands office and our gaming group loved it. I can't wait to try this with hazelnut butter!

text:
Sorry, I did not care for this fudge.  It is easy to make, but when  it called for boiling for two minutes (not using a candy thermometer) it made me nervous.  I've made many batches of fudge as well as hard candies.  The sugar mixture doesn't boil long enough to dissolve the sugar, it ends up with a grainy texture.  I like fudge to be very smooth.  I know it's fudge but this was exceptionally sweet.  My four girls however loved this fudge.  If it wasn't for them, it would still be sitting here from Christmas.  Easy to make, but not the taste/texture of fudge I prefer.

My great grandma used to make peanut butter fudge for Christmas.  It was my only fond memory of visiting she and my grandfather.  Noone in the family ever got the recipe from her before she passed.  When I wanted some, I was very disappointed in the recipes I tried, until this one.

Right on for creaminess and taste.  I'll be making it every year now.  Thanks for helping me get back a happy memory, and a lost family recipe!

text:
I made this for Christmas and it flew off the plate.  My adult kids and grandkids couldn't get enough of it.  I changed the amounts to: 2 cups brown sugar, 1 cup peanut butter and 3 cups confectioner's sugar.  Spread half into a 4 x 4 pan then added chopped walnuts to the other half and spread it into a 4/x/4 pan.  Both kinds were devoured.  This is deffinately sweeter than chocolate fudge, but oh sooooooooo good.  Will be making this again.

The taste was wonderful, but at higher altitudes the recipe needs to be adjusted for texture.  If you are cooking in a higher altitude, you may want to reduce the amount of powdered sugar to 3 cups and add as you see fit.  I made this recipe and it was a little crumbly, but it would have been solved with less powdered sugar.

This recipe is good for a quick fudge. However, you can still feel the tiny grainy texture of confectionner's sugar. I won't look for another PB fudge recipe though, for this one is quick and satisfying. text:
I took this for a church dessert night, and less than 1/4 was eaten.  This was good fudge, but not a spectacular dessert in general, I guess.  It did crumble when cut, so the pieces didn't look perfect.  In response to other reviews: 1) If your fudge doesn't harden properly, you haven't boiled it long enough.  When it says "boil for 2 minutes" that is referring to a rapid boil, not a few occasionaly bubbles.  2) For those who found they got "pebbles" when stirring the mixture into the confectioner's sugar, use less confectioner's sugar.  The suggestion to use the 3 cups of confectioner's sugar, 2 cups of brown sugar, and 1 cup of peanut butter is what I did.  3) The suggestion to add cocoa powder to 1/3 of the mix and then swirl it in sounds great, but specifics weren't given. I'm guessing you'd add about 1 1/2 Tbsp. cocoa powder to the 1/3 mixture BEFORE pouring it into the confectioner's sugar.  I don't really know how you'd swirl it in either.  It's pretty dry.  I'd love to hear how to do it, though.  Chocolate makes everything better!
Review:
Rating:
4
dateLastModified:
2004-08-30T11:32:26.437
helpfulCount:
1

398947

This was great! This was the first time I made a fudge of any kind, and it was delicious! I made these for my mother to take to work, because every day until Christmas everyone is supposed to bring something to work to share. It's great because it has the things even the most vague of bakers has lying around the house. I didn't think it was going to be that good because it tasted kind of funny while it was still hot, plus that seemed like a LOT of powdered sugar... But after it was chilled, it was totally transformed-- I had to keep reminding myself that I was supposed to be on a diet and stuff it in the very back of the fridge so it was hard to get to!

text:
I'm surprised at all the great reviews. Maybe I should've followed the reviewer's adjustments bc I, too, followed this to a T (since I lost my last deliciously unbeatable pb fudge recipe) and was quite disappointed with the results. I had no issues smoothing it out (I used the hand mixer for a while) but I did have issues with it hardening. Not that I like hard fudge but this batch continued to be too soft even after hours in the fridge. The kind of soft where you slice out cuts and hours later they're fusing back together again. Not great for serving at a party.

Those having trouble with consistency, I suggest using real butter and real brown sugar (read the ingredients...not sugar and molasses). Also, for the newer cooks....confectioners sugar is powdered sugar, not regular sugar

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Way more details needed for this recipe. Like other reviewers I got "pebbles" when I blended sugar and peanut butter mixture with confectioners sugar. I suspect the culprit is that I used natural peanut butter rather than typical store brands that have hydrogenated oils added for smoother texture. Also, it doesn't specify salted or unsalted butter or how many servings it makes. I was able to somewhat rescue this fudge by adding 2/3 cup hot cream while blending with sugar. That improved the flavor too but still wicked sweet. I will serve it at home but not as a gift.

Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2018-12-28T20:13:24.247
helpfulCount:
0
userID:
4013265
Display Name:
Michelle Booher
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
24
favoritesCount:
98
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/7013236.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is the only peanut butter fudge recipe I'll ever use.  As per other suggestions, went up to a heaping cup of peanut butter and down to about 2.5 cups of powdered sugar and 2 cups of brown sugar.  Depending on what I'm doing with it, I sometimes add corn starch for a little more body.   I also use margarine and water instead of milk and butter, turning this into a truly non-dairy fudge.   It might taste better with milk and butter, I don't know, but I know that nobody I've given it to can tell the difference.

I have done all kinds of things with this fudge.  I've piped it into silicone candy molds, waited until it set, and then popped in the freezer until frozen solid.  Coated in chocolate or uncoated, these make amazing candies.  Right now, it's setting in a  chocolate cookie crumb pie mold.   It'll be way too rich to be rightly called pie, but I'm guessing it's going to go over well, regardless.

Point being:  This is a versatile recipe that can do a lot more than make squares of fudge.  It's pretty easy to make, low mess, and fairly forgiving, so it's ideal for when you want to get creative.
Review:
Rating:
5

text:
Recipe turned out wonderfully! Make sure you stir the butter, sugar and milk mixture constantly while bringing to a boil to dissolve all of the sugar. Keep stirring once boiling for two whole minutes then remove from heat and mix in your pb and vanilla. If you follow the recipe exactly, it will turn out perfect! Will definitely make it again, and I love the fact that I could make an excellent fudge without marshmallows or evaporated milk!

text:
We have made this fudge a couple of dozen times. It is great but old Harry likes nuts in fudge so we added 1/2 cup of chopped walnuts after all the mixing is done because if any earlier it may be a little harder to get all the little lumps of confectioners sugar. It did not crumble, it only did what it was suppose to do, every time. One time I made a mistake and added twice the confectioners sugar. I just made twice the fudge. When I printed the recipe it called for 2 ¼ cups of brown sugar. That is what I go by. The confectioners sugar is about ¼ cup less than a one pound bag so I just add the entire bag. It does not make any mess :) I would add a picture but all you would see is an empty dish. Thanks for the recipe.

text:
Was very smooth and creamy but I think instead of the peanut butter I will try a bag of peanut butter mixed with chocolate chips .. Overall, the texture was good and I did have to cook mine a little more then 4 minutes before adding powdered sugar and   Peanut butter. I always put a little bit of water in a bowl and add  just a tsp of the boiled mixture  in the bowl and if you can form it into a soft ball then the fudge is ready to take off stove so you can add the  peanut butter and confectioner sugar. I Learned that little trick from my grandma that had no candy thermometer... lol... Good Luck if you give this method  a try!

text:
I made two different kinds of fudge today. One chocolate and one peanut butter. I used this recipe except I followed the suggestions of 2cups brown sugar, 3 cups powdered sugar and 1 cup peanut butter. This turned out awesome! My chocolate one was dry and crumbly. I cooked this one at a lower heat so maybe thats why it didn't crumble. I didn't use a candy thermometer. Really great though. I used honey peanut butter and the extra sugars didn’t affect it negatively.

userID:
8415992
Display Name:
cookin'gal
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0

0
favoritesCount:
126
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674155.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I mistakenly added the peanut butter and milk to the melted butter and brown sugar before cooking the butter and sugar for 2 minutes. So I cooked the whole mix for 2 minutes. I then added the peanut butter mix to the 10X sugar in the bowl of my stand mixer and beat it for less than a minute. It was the perfect consistency, forming a soft clump that fell out of the bowl into my 8”x8” dish. I just pressed it evenly in the dish and let it cool. Like other reviewers, I used 2 cups of brown sugar, 1cup of peanut butter, and 3 cups of 10x sugar. It was good, but a little too sweet, so the next time I will cut one of the sugars back a bit. Consistency was fine.
Review:

1

I am 50 years old and have NEVER been able to make fudge.  No matter how hard I tried, I just couldn't get it right.  So after having some pretty pricey fudge from a gourmet gift shop last night, I decided to try again.  I am very glad to report that this fudge turned out wonderfully!!!  It is just a teeny bit soft, but not bad.  I will chalk it up to humidity since it's been raining all day.   I did read many reviews and decided to make the suggested modifications to the sugars & peanut butter.  It's really delicious and I am thrilled!  Thank you again for posting the recipe and to everyone who offered advice in their reviews.

text:
I've made this recipe many times and it always turns out amazing! The only thing I started to change after a few times was the amount of peanut butter. Instead of three fourths of a cup, I upped it to a whole cup. Mostly because I was too lazy to measure it so tediously, when extra peanut butter is definitely not anything to complain about Also I noticed some reviewers saying that theirs pebbles up too much, make sure you measure your confectioners sugar correctly, too much makes it dry, and also don't cook the peanut butter mixture for too long!

text:
I used 2 C. brown sugar, 3 C. confectioner's, and 1 C. peanut butter.   The trick in the end is to use a good mixer like a Kitchen Aid to blend in the confectioner's sugar.  Perfect every time, I live above 7000 feet and still no problem.

I make this along with a 1/2 batch substituting the "1 Cup peanut butter" with "2 cups chocolate morsels" and pour the chocolate on top of the peanut butter to get 2/3 peanut butter and 1/3 chocolate fudge on top.   A perfect combination.

userID:
21285029
Display Name:
sg1973
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
1
favoritesCount:

recipesCount:

reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614249.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've been making this recipe for many years now after experimenting with several other recipes for peanut butter fudge.  Most recipes I found came out very dry and crumbly.  But this one comes out perfect every time.  I see no reason to change the ingredients.  It has a rich peanut butter flavor and perfect texture.  Yes, of course it is sweet (it's candy)!  This recipe works well if you boil it for 2 minutes  beginning when you first start to see bubbles.  If you wait for a rolling boil before you start timing you will probably end up with a grainy texture.  The secret is to work quickly once you take it off the heat.  I don't recommend beating with an electric mixer.  Use a spoon.  Stir vigorously by hand and as soon as you feel it begin to stiffen, immediately stop and pour it into the pan to set.   You may still have a few tiny clumps of powdered sugar.  But resist the temptation to beat until every last clump of powdered sugar is dissolved.  You will likely end up with fudge that is unworkable and sets up in your mixing bowl.  Once set it is smooth and creamy every time.

I had the problem with crumbly fudge in my mixing bowl. What I did was dump it in my prepared pan and pressed the fudge in to the pan firmly and leveled the fudge out as best I could. Since the mix was still warm it came together and looked fine. Taste is great!
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2016-12-22T19:57:01.547
helpfulCount:
0
userID:
555975
Display Name:
LA Homespun
isPro:
False
followersCount:
4
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
39
favoritesCount:
538
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/302894.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I followed the tips by OkinawanPrincess and used 2 cups of brown sugar, increased the PB to 1 cup and decreased the confx sugar to 3 cups. I used a heavy-duty stainless steel pan over number 3 gas flame. Stir all till it starts to bubble while stirring and STOP after if does or it will be grainy. Start timer for 2 mins and boil. Remove off of stove after and place on hot pad, add peanut butter and mix into boiled mixture with mixer then add confx sugar a little at a time while mixing till all combined for about 2 mins. Don't forget to add the vanilla also. I placed mine in a wax paper lined pan and it cut beautifully and was creamy and smooth in texture. It sat up correctly also. Very good recipe that I'll use again!
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2016-12-22T01:55:28.63
helpfulCount:

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is the BEST peanut butter fudge I have tasted!!  Plus it is so easy to make!  I doubled the recipe without any problem.  But like some others did I added a whole cup of peanut butter to my doubled recipe.
Also, when I added the liquid ingredients to the powdered sugar and I used my mixer to mix the fudge, by the time it got smooth, it was pretty well to set up.  So instead of pouring it into the pans, I pressed it into the pans.
Also to address the problem of not setting up that some of the other reveiwers experienced, make sure you DO NOT USE DIET margarine or diet butter!  Diet margarine won't set up for ANY fudge.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614252.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Awesome fudge!  I'm not sure of the rating etiquette on here but it lost a star because I did not follow the recipe as it's listed.  Following others' recommendations I lowered sugar to 2C Brown Sugar, 3C Confectioners Sugar and upped the Peanut Butter to a HEAPING cup (probably closer to 1 1/8 cups) but I don't think you could do wrong going up to 1 1/4 or 1 1/2 cups peanut butter.  I'm going to try 1 1/2 cups next time and compare.  I'd also note that I used JIF peanut butter (the regular creamy kind), not Smuckers Natural or raw peanut butter or anything like that as those products don't have oils in them to prevent separation, and I'd assume negative reviews on here that encountered separation *may* have not used a non-separating peanut butter...   I also added chopped candied pecans to the confectioners sugar and it added a wonderful crunchy addition to the fudge.  This fudge was incredibly creamy, tasty, and I'd pit it against any peanut butter fudge purchased on Mackinac Island.  I think I'm going to pair it with a chocolate fudge recipe and layer the 2.  S&%*'s about to get real!

country:
None
text:
This is my favorite fudge base. I read the other reviews too and did 2 C. brown sugar, 3 C. confectioner's, and 1 C. peanut butter. But, I omitted the vanilla (out of it) and added a cup of mini marshmallows to the butter/brown sugar mixture once the two were blended together well. Cooked on low stirring constant. Upped it a little higher in heat, where they began to melt. Once they did, on medium stirring constant. Once I timed the 2 mins, I removed it, added peanut butter, than on top of the conf. sugar, andused my beater on high. Wonderful. Would be awesome with walnuts.

I went with the 2c. brown sugar, 3c confectioner's (icing sugar), and 1c. peanut butter that others suggested, and it's a hit!! It's nice and peanut-buttery which the right amount of sweet. I chilled it for just over an hour in a skillet, since I didn't have a small 8x8 pan, which means the pieces weren't perfectly square, but who cares. I probably could have chilled a little bit longer before serving, but we still enjoyed it, and we have tons left :)

text:
With the changes others mentioned, it is excellent (I used  3 -2-1 for the ratio). I make this every year.  Be careful to not let the boiling sugar mixture get too hot or boil for too long, or you will get the gritty / pebble texture & the butter  will separate to the top. Occasionally I get a thin greasy layer on top & I just dab it off with a paper towel.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Had to take a quick second this Christmas morning to post a review of this recipe.   I made it on the spur of the moment to take to the family get-together today, after reading the reviews and making the same adjustments many others made (2 C brown sugar, 1 C peanut butter, 3 C powdered sugar). I had no trouble with this recipe at all!  Set my timer for two minutes after the butter/sugar came to a rolling boil, and had the powdered sugar waiting in the bowl of my stand mixer with the paddle attachment ready to go.  Stirred in the peanut butter and vanilla until incorporated, poured the mixture into the stand mixer, and mixed on low until blended.  In seconds it was one big mass of warm fudge that pulled away from the sides of the bowl.  Pressed it into a pan and chilled in the fridge.  Based on what we licked from the bowl, I can't wait to serve it to family today!  I think it'll become a Christmas tradition...maybe add mini chocolate chips next year??  Hope you try it!

text:
I tried this fudge because it's Christmas Eve and I didn't have marshmallow cream for my regular peanut butter fudge recipe.  To my delight it was easy and tastes wonderful.  I read the reviews first and decided to follow the suggestions to use 3 cups confectioners sugar, 2 cups brown sugar, and 1 cup crunchy peanut butter.  The only other thing I changed was I had some whipping cream in the refrigerator so I mixed it half and half with skim milk.  It was creamy, easy to put in the square pan and set up very quickly.  I hope I don't eat it all before I take it for Christmas tomorrow.

text:
Ok, I've been making fudge for years, and I'm very particular about consistency. I started with the typical marshmallow fudge, moved on to more challenging fudge and then when I was out of PB chips, I decided to give this one a shot. I hated it at first when I was stirring in the p.sugar. It looked awful and spread worse. I thought there was no way I was giving it to anyone. I'm used to fudge that pours and you can make pretty designs in before it sets up. This came out more like a dough initially and I basically had to press it out with my hands(I refused to use a rolling pin for fudge). BUT, the way it set up, while not super pretty, had a great consistency! I love a good dry fudge and this really had that. I may end up using this any time I'm making PB fudge unless I'm just really hung up on the way it looks. :)

text:
Holy smokes is this SUPER sweet. Way way too sweet. I followed the recipe for the most part. I used dark brown sugar since that's what I had opened and I added 1c of PB. Not enough PB flavor at all. The texture is nice, but the PB flavor, even with adding that little bit extra is not enough. The PB is very very subtle and the pure sweetness of this fudge overpowers everything. 
Also, I was having a problem I saw on another review where the mixture was clumpy after pouring it over the powdered sugar. I had to use my electric hand mixer to get all the little sugar lumps out, but it worked like a charm and ended up smooth. Not sure I'll be making this one again.

text:
I absolutely LOVE this recipe! The first time I made it it turned out too sticky and a little too sweet, and it also had little clumps of powdered sugar in it- even after beating it forever. So the second time I made it, I let the mixture on the stove boil for a little longer so that it would thicken up a little more, and I only used 3 cups of powdered sugar instead of 3 1/2, and then I sifted the powdered sugar, too so that there wouldn't be any clumps this time..then put it in a square pan to chill in the fridge and it was perfect!! The best I have ever had! Everyone else that tried it was super impressed and surprised at how good it was as well, no one could get enough of it! It has only been a week since I discovered this recipe and I have already just made the third batch! Yummmm!!!

I always made peanut butter fudge the old fashioned way, with white sugar, and much more milk, boiling for a long time to get soft ball stage. This fudge is sweet, but then again it is CANDY! I will probably still make my old fashioned recipe as I have every holiday season since my wife and I were married (43 years) but I will also make this recipe in addition.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe is the best homemade I've tried (besides my grandma's). I've tried finding many different convenient peanut butter fudge recipes but they didn't taste right. I tried the "easy" microwave fudge it was so gross I wouldn't eat it. This was smooth and rich in flavor. I followed the recipe but took out the brown sugar that's the only thing I didn't add. I also added a little more vanilla. I let it set in the fridge for 2 hours and it turned out great! Very quick, convenient and tasty! Also to help others when I took it off the stove and added a little confectioners sugar it turned pebbley so I put it back on the stove and heated it back up until it melted what little sugar I added, I took it back off the stove and slowly whipped (didn't use a mixer, mixed by hand) until it started getting smooth. I only added in a cup at a time and whipped it until fully mixed.

Excellent! Everyone is a huge peanut butter fan in the house so I make this more than standard chocolate fudge. I'm a huge chocolate person but I actually prefer this peanut butter fudge, it's so good! I had never made fudge before so I followed the recipe exactly. It came out wonderful! Perfect if you have a mega sweet tooth. I also added some semi-sweet chocolate chips and some Reece peanut butter chips.

text:
I followed the recipe to a "T", even didn't start timer until it was at a full rolling boil, but it will not set up unless kept in refrigerator.  I had a feeling the peanut butter (I used Jif creamy) should not have been added to boiling mixture because it melted right away. I'm definitely going to try everyone's recommendations to adjust sugar & peanut butter amounts but I am also going to add peanut butter to powdered sugar and let butter mixture cool next time.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677172.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Good recipe, but wayyyy too sweet. After reading reviews, I cut down sugar to 2 c. brown, 3 c. confectioners', and upped the PB to 1 cup. Still a bit too sweet, even for a rich dessert like fudge. However, the recipe seems to adapt itself very well to changes, so next time I will use natural peanut butter, decrease the confectioners' and decrease the butter to 6 tbsp. However, I think the base recipe could make a fantastic peanut butter fudge frosting 

Some of the tips I collected that were useful: 
- Sift your confectioners' sugar and use an electric beater to mix it in 
- Start timing the two minutes AFTER is starts boiling
- Line the pan with buttered parchment paper for easy removal and less cleanup

Btw, if you use the quantities I said above, the whole pans comes to 5,000 calories, 120 calories per serving if you cut it into 42 squares.

I cannot wait to sink my teeth into this!  I have always stayed away from pb fudge recipes because I fail at them.  This one is GREAT! I did read all the reviews and adjust my amounts as most others did.  I licked the beaters and scraped a bit from the mixing bowl and it is wonderful!  I can tell already it will come out great by how it went into the pan, perfect consistency.  I also discovered that the mixture before adding to the confectioner's sugar tastes awesome and would be a wonderful ice cream topping.  I'm going to experiment and make another batch and stop there and see what happens.  I was thinking it would keep nicely in a jar in the fridge and then warm the amount you need for topping.  Excellent recipe, thank you for sharing!

text:
I tried this but doubled up on everything because I just wanted to make a bigger batch.  It turned out perfectly and I did everything by hand.  I mixed the peanut butter and powdered sugar by massaging it together with my hands and then I poured the rest into the mixing boil after it was boiling for two minutes.  Because it was so hot and I began stirring immediately, the peanut butter melted just fine and everything blended perfectly and in just a few minutes.  I used a whisk and a mixing bowl and it turned out 100% perfect.

text:
To each their own, but our family loved this recipe. Of course it's sweet, it's fudge! And peanut butter flavor (and even sweetness to some degree) is easily adjustable to taste. Careful though, as too much adjusting with sugar and/or peanut butter could affect the texture. I added an additional tablespoon of peanut butter and it was great. But then, I like sweet...I eat less if I get a good dose of sugar in one small piece. :) I will whisk my powdered sugar first next time, as it is quite hard to get it " lump free" by hand. Overall great and super easy  recipe!

I have made this recipe 3 times now. The first 2 times it came out perfect, but this last time, I got the pebbles like so many others, and the butter separated. To try to salvage it, I put it all back in a pan on the stove over medium heat, added the rest of the jar of peanut butter and another 1/2 cup of milk, and beat it with the mixer while it cooked a little longer, until it was smooth and pourable. It's in the fridge now, so we will see how this turns out. Like the others, I'm wondering what went wrong?? Like I said, I've made it before flawlessly, so it must be something with a chemical reaction somewhere.

text:
So, when I made this I didn't carefully read the instructions and added the peanut butter during the cooking process.  I followed the advice from other reviews and used 2 C brown sugar and 3 C confectioners sugar.  I used a cup of PB, which I stirred in with the brown sugar and milk. I almost threw it out when I realized my mistake after consulting the recipe, but I went ahead and brought it to a boil, cooked for 2 min as instructed.  I tossed in about another 1/4 PB with the vanilla and then sifted in the confectioners sugar as I blended.  Came out creamy, smooth and delicious!!

Okay, this recipe uses the perfect amount of ingredients and instructions make for a wonderfully creamy fudge. With that being said, it was HORRIBLY SWEET. Realizing it was too much sugar while I was making it, I used 2 cups of brown sugar and 3 cups of confectioners sugar. Even at that I found it too sweet. I too used 1 C peanut butter (chunky). 

I think next time I'm using 2.75 C of Brown Sugar and 2.5 C of powdered sugar.

text:
Amazing fudge!  Wonderfully light and a little fluffy, yet still rich.  I use Smuckers Natural peanut butter, which lends a better PB taste than some of the other types.  I've made this recipe 3 times now, and it always comes out perfect.  I also use the modification recommended in the reviews: 1 cup PB, 2 cups brown sugar, and 3 cups powdered sugar.  Also, start the 2 minute timing as soon as you see small bubbles, and I typically stir constantly while boiling.  So easy, so FAST, and everyone loves it!!

text:
This was my first time making fudge.  I did the recommended modifications. 3 c cofectioners, 2 c brown, 1 c peanut butter.  It was still super sweet - like fudge should be!  Once the butter mixture began to bubble, timed it for 2 minutes exactly.  Used a hand mixer to get out all lumps and sprayed pan with non stick spray.  It set up beautifully and was not crumbly at all.  Perfectly creamy.

Poured peanut butter mixture over xx sugar  and immediately started beating it.  It did not go into crumbly pebbles this time, it beat right into a creamy mixture.  Put into pan I had already prepped w/PAM, foil, Pam, and it started setting up right away.

text:
I made this fudge for the first time today and it is both super simple and delicious.  Using the recommendations in other posts, I made it with 2c of brown sugar, 1c of peanut butter and 3c of confectioners' sugar.  I also lined the pan with plastic wrap, which made it slide right out.  I prefer my fudge on the soft side, so I started the 2 minute boil timer when it first bubbled in the center and the consistency is perfect.  This will now be my go-to peanut butter fudge recipe.
