They turned out a bit dry and crumbly, but I think I let the peanut butter mixture cool too much before adding it to the powdered sugar. And, although a little dry, it's delicious!! I will definitely try this recipe again!

None
text:
The fudge is still cooling, and I'm still picking off the little pieces and chunks that took to flying around the kitchen and attaching themselves to everywhere they landed when I was using the electric beater.  I couldn't even get mixer to med speed cuz the flying objects became like  heat seeking missiles.  If I had put it on high, I'd have taken out my husband, dog, and plants , So, I beat it on just above low. And like in so many more reviews, it was in pieces and chunky, never even made it to clumpy... I followed another survivers review and added 2 tbls milk... It got creamy smooth and sticky... Stuck it in 8x8 pan and put in fridge... It was really sweet, maybe semi sweet choc. frosting might tone it down.. If I can get it out of pan when it cools, I'll taste it again and see if it's worth it,   jwmudd

I have never had much luck making fudge and i was afraid i had fouled this one up when it became so stiff that my mixer couldnt handle it and "pouring" it into the pan was impossible. I wasn't sure if this was supposed to go in the fridge to chill or just left out to cool. I put it in the fridge but it got too hard to cut so i had to let it get to room temp. before cutting.

I am a gal who loves to eat.  So please take me seriously when I say this might be the best thing I have ever eaten!  I followed the recipe to a T - with one slight addition, a candy thermometer!  
I made chocolate fudge first so when I got to this recipe I thought the texture looked really off and was concerned.  NO reason to be concerned!  This fudge was part of a Christmas gift basket that I have given several pieces and has met RAVE reviews from one and all!  In fact, I have some left in the fridge to make up one last basket for a few friends I will see tomorrow night, and I can't keep my paws off!  I will need to make another batch!  (What a shame!)  Cheap, easy, decadent and WONDERFUL!!!

text:
Fabulous fudge.  I took the suggestion of many and cut the brown sugar to 2 cups and the powdered sugar to 3 cups.  I sifted the powdered sugar into my kitchenaide mixer bowl and then dumped the fudge mixture into it and beat until smooth.  Sooo bad for you but sooo good!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Per the reviews, I scaled down powdered sugar to 3 cups (good thing, it was VERY thick even with this) and upped peanut butter to one cup.

Here is the thing, it tastes JUST like the center of a "buckeye" christmas cookie.  Those are the peanut butter balls dipped in chocolate.  Which I love, but arent quite the same thing as fudge to me.

These are more sweet than peanut-buttery, even with the increase in PB- I can only sort of barely make out the pb taste.  I've been trying various peanut butter fudge recipes on this site and I think  I will keep looking.  Not enough peanut butter taste but not a bad sweet treat overall.

By the way if you use a 8 by 8 pan it make for pretty tall fudge (the picture is accurate).  You could probably use a slightly larger for lower-profile fudge.

I really did not care for this recipe, but I am sure it has something to do with the problems I had.

text:
This recipe tastes great. I did have a big problem with the sugar turning into hundreds of tiny pebbles, like another reviewer, so I quickly switched to an electric mixer, which helped greatly. It is almost lump-free, but not entirely. The taste is worth it. I highly recommend a hand-held mixer, though. I also used reduced-fat peanut butter and you can't even tell the difference--the powdered sugar is so sweet that the missing sugar from the PB is not noticeable.

None
text:
I followed the user comments and used 3 C. confectioner's sugar, 1 C. PB and 2 C. brown sugar.  When I beat the mixture with the confectioner's sugar it never became smooth... not even close.  I added a little milk though and then it was fine (a little milk goes a long way when adding it this way).  Overall it turned out fine, although I think it had slightly too much of a brown sugar taste.

text:
Sets a little soft and is very sweet. However the flavor and the creamy texture more than make up for any cons. NOTE: It sets up very very quickly and it takes a fair few minutes to beat the living hell out of (i.e. get the little balls of powdered sugar out). If at first it is lumpy, beat harder. (Think of the little engine who could!)

text:
this recipe is awesome. I woke up this morning with a strong pregnancy craving for peanut butter fudge. I've never made fudge before, and after ruining 2 batches (crumbled oily mess)using a different recipe from this site, i tried this as a last ditch effort. i had used up all the fluff i had making the first 2 batches but had everything for this recipe on hand. thank goodness. i followed user review suggestions and used 2 cups brown sugar, 1 cup p.b., and 3 cups of conf. sugar. i sifted the confectioners sugar, and only actually had to use about 2 1/2 cups of it to get my fudge to the pefect consistancy. it was too thick to pour but i used a piece of plasic wrap and the flat bottom of a cup to press it into the pan and smooth the top and it came out perfect. thanks so much for sharing, i'll definately make this again!

text:
Well, this goes down as my first kitchen fire! The brown sugar/butter mixture boiled over onto my burner and actual flames came up. Wow! Nonetheless, this recipe came out okay, I think. It ended up making 2.5 pans but maybe I should have put more in each pan. The consistency still isn't firm (it was in the fridge overnight). But I have never been very successful with fudge making (that's why I picked one called "Easiest"). At any rate, most of my problems are user issues, not the recipe. I guess I'll stick with store-bought fudge!

text:
I'm not sure what I did to mess this up, but I did! I followed the other reviewers suggestions and did 1c PB, 2C Brown Sugar, and 3C 10x, and I kept it at a rolling boil for 2 minutes but this just didn't set up properly. I had to put it into the freezer to be able to cut it into squares. Although it didn't set up right, the flavor is out of this world! YUMMY! Hmmm, maybe next time I'll try the original recipe and see if it goes better. Seriously though, if you aren't fudge-disabled like me, give this a try because it is so tasty!

text:
I had a hard time with this receipe. The fudge set up before all the powdered sugar was incorporated. I had a bowl of what looked like brown sand. After some internet research on fudge, I decided I overbeat it by using a hand-held mixer to beat the sugar in. I fixed it by reheating the whole thing with some half-and-half. After it melted back down, it poured and set up great. Taste is fantastic.

The suggestion to use the electric beater to incorporte the peanut butter into the brown sugar/butter mixture is a very good one!

text:
This is the first fudge I've made, and it was indeed really easy with this recipe. I doubled the recipe, using a 9 X 13 pan. Some reviewers have said that this fudge doesn't harden enough, and I guess I can see how they'd say that about the fudge after it has been sitting out for awhile, but it doesn't get *that* soft. Also, I think it tastes plenty peanut buttery. Thanks Angie!
